Message.Title: AMZN hires 70,000 seasonal employees
Message.Msg: The AMZN valuation implies that the company is a growth company with significant operating leverage. Yet, every time the company speaks of increasing revenue, whether seasonal or not, they always need to open new distribution centers and hire more employees. This is such an old line retail business model. Marginal revenue and marginal cost correlation is nearly linear. If you measure valuable growth by increasing operating margins and EPS growth, AMZN doesn't fit the bill of a growth stock. The company is about as exciting as Sears, Best Buy or any other retailer that sources a majority of its revenues during the Xmas season and then processes returns in January - Boring. The growth stock charade can't go on forever.

Message.Title: AMZN now 21st largest Market cap in S&P500
Message.Msg: In the past 4 weeks it is up 11.3%, moving from 24 to 21 by passing Verizon, Merck, and Philip Morris. If it goes up just 3% more it will move up 4 more spots to 17 and pass Citigroup, Bank of America, Visa and Oracle. This is staggering to even think about. The amazing thing is that it is all on complete speculation: - someday they may make a profit - someday that profit will turn into fat enough margins to support the current stock price. - someday they may find economies of scale and their investments will lag revenue growth - someday they will be able to raise prices as all competition will be gone including eBay, WMT, apple, samsung and google - they are hiring 70k people, so that must mean a great holiday season. Maybe they just continue to be inefficent and the 70k is needed becuase of the inefficiency and low ROIC (due to build out of the fulfillment centers, they need more people in more places than ever before). All of the companies above have proved it and have delivered. Amazon is hope. The 17th most valuable company in America is based on "hope" that someday it will work out? Topic.Title: AMZN now 21st largest Market cap in S&P500

Message.Msg: Maybe they have to hire more people because they have more locations... Just as with inventory, where the optimal level required to maintain certain service levels increases with the number of nodes in the network, so too the required company wide staffing increases (and the supposed scale efficiencies are reduced). Amazon is pursuing a highly vulnerable middling strategy. If UPS/FedEx decides to risk losing some Amazon business (and the other follow's suit) be leveling the playing field between Amazon and other retailers on shipping charges (which would NOT be anti-competitive... it would force Amazon to compete on equal terms...), Amazon is simply phucked. It doesn't really have the cost structure and efficiency everyone thinks it does.

Topic.Title: AMZN now 21st largest Market cap in S&P500

Message.Msg: Then there's the issue with 3rd party/FBA inventory optimization and fulfillment. FWIW, it is why Amazon created the inventory financing program for FBA customers...But that is for another time.
